title: 111_s1832
content: The "Small Business Access to Capital Act of 2009" amends Section 7(a) of the Small Business Act to increase the loan percentage from 75% to 90% and raise the loan amount from $1,500,000 to $4,500,000. Additionally, it introduces low-interest refinancing under the Local Development Business Loan Program. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow refinancing of existing debt for small businesses without expansion, as long as the financing amount is not more than 80% of the collateral value and the business has been operating for at least 2 years. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow refinancing of existing debt for small businesses without expansion, as long as certain conditions are met, including the borrower agreeing to pay a fee for any additional costs incurred. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to allow refinancing of existing debt for small businesses without expansion, regardless of job creation goals. SEC. 4. MICROLOANS. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the percentage of grants provided to intermediaries. Additionally, the maximum microloan amount is raised from $35,000 to $50,000. Section 7(m)(4) of the Small Business Act is amended to increase the percentage of grants provided to intermediaries and raise the maximum microloan amount from $35,000 to $50,000. SEC. 5 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to increase maximum loan amounts under the 504 program to $5,000,000. SEC. 6 addresses new markets venture capital company investment limitations. Section 355 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include investment limitations for covered New Markets Venture Capital companies. These companies are defined as those approved by the Administrator after March 1, 2002, and have received financing. They are restricted from acquiring securities for any single enterprise exceeding 10 percent of their regulatory capital without Administrator approval. The amendment to Section 355 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 introduces investment limitations for covered New Markets Venture Capital companies. These companies, approved by the Administrator after March 1, 2002, are restricted from acquiring securities exceeding 10 percent of their regulatory capital without Administrator approval. The limitations include disclosing the regulatory capital and projected leverage in the participation agreement. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 is amended to allocate $150,000,000 to the National Institutes of Health for extramural research and development. Additionally, the Business Stabilization Program undergoes amendments regarding investment limitations for covered New Markets Venture Capital companies. SEC. 9. PROSPECTIVE REPEALS. Amendments made to the Small Business Act and the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 will take effect on October 1, 2010. Changes include adjusting percentages and loan amounts for business loans and refinancing programs.
